Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Controls on Water Isotope Variability in the Tropical Pacific: A Strategy to Improve Paleoclimate Interpretations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Paleoclimate reconstructions of past tropical precipitation rely on interpreting hydrogen and oxygen isotopic variations in terms of past changes in precipitation. This project has the goal of better understanding of the response of tropical Pacific precipitation to climatic variability and how the stable isotope composition of the rainfall is affected by seasonal and interannual changes in the climate. The researchers include a scientist and a postdoctoral fellow from Georgia Institute of Technology and a scientist from the University of Colorado. They will collect and measure the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes in water vapor, rainfall and seawater from four island locations in the tropical Pacific. Samples will be collected on site during field programs executed by the PIs. The sampling program will also include year-round sampling by local individuals who will be trained in proper sampling techniques. The sampling strategy includes ultra high-resolution sampling of the diurnal cycle, as well as daily and longer sampling in order to evaluate the relationship of water isotope variability to climate change from sub-seasonal to interannual time scales and on a basin wide scale. The stable isotope data will be integrated with an isotope-enabled climate model at the National Center for Atmospheric Research to link the climate mechanisms for the isotope variability at high frequency with the resulting longer term averaged values that typify the type of data reconstructed by paleoclimate proxies of rainfall. Using this approach, the PIs hope to provide a more accurate evaluation of paleoclimate proxies as well as a better understanding of the uncertainties embedded in these types of reconstructions.

The recent rise in the number of paleoclimate publications dedicated to measuring and interpreting water stable isotopes, and the possibly oversimplified nature of some of the interpretations, makes this project likely to have a significant impact on paleoclimate research. The project includes two established researchers, Kim Cobb (GA. Tech.) and David Noone (CU), but the main driver of this project is Jessica Conroy, an EAR Postdoctoral Research Fellow at Ga. Tech., supported by the AGS Paleoclimate Program. This project builds on the PRF award by providing greater access to the Pacific for sampling, collaboration with Noone at CU for access to the NCAR GCMs, and a third year of support for the postdoc to complete the work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new rainwater and seawater collection network was established at four sites across the tropical Pacific: Galápagos, Kiritimati, Palau, and Papua New Guinea, to construct a new datasets of the stable water isotope ratios in the tropical Pacific. From the network of data we have found that the d18O seawater-salinity relationship, which underpins many paleoclimatic reconstructions from this region, is broadly robust, however, significant deviations arise. The relationship is not constant on different time scales, nor is uniform in space. Part of the explanation for this result stems from being able to better resolve the impact of regional precipitation and oceanic circulation using the high resolution data and local effects. At the Galapagos site, for instance, strong vertical dependence of the isotope ratios on the altitude from which the rainwater was sampled on Santa Cruz Island allows different histories of evaporative enrichment as the water flow within the porous volcanic lithology of overland to the coastal areas and subsequently outflow to the coastal marine environment. Consequently, records recovered from areas in which local island outflow are important should amount for evaporation effects and potentially the use of deuterium excess in sea water, and 17-Oxygen excess in carbonates, could resolve this influence in paleoclimate records. Results from both Manus Island and the Galapagos are consistent with modeling work that shows that the monthly correlations with precipitation amount (the “amount effect”) is not coherent on event, or even sub-event, time scales. The relationship is not constant on different time scales, nor is uniform in space. The linear decomposition into these terms that represent these processes account for the correlation between moisture convergence and precipitation rate, and therefore the source origin effect is distinguished from the rain intensity effect. We find that isotopic variations in some proxy records are associated with changes in tropical hydrology that are more comprehensive than simply changes to precipitation intensity. A theoretical framework that was designed to differentiate different types of cloud processes to evaluate the different types of processes which influence the amount effect across the Indo-Pacific region. By distinguishing cloud processes using the bulk behavior of isotopic ratios relative to the specific humidity, several geographically-distinct descriptions emerge and would be relevant for interpretation records from those areas. The implication of the analysis is that the isotope-climate relationships that one might use to reconstruct past climate should differ substantially, and indeed no region shows evidence for validity of the simple description of the isotope ratios as being dependent solely on the precipitation amount. Given these findings we have placed bounds on the uncertainty associated with deriving past climate information from isotopic proxy records in the tropical Pacific and provided an improved mechanistic description of controls on the proxy records i that leads to a more accurate climatic interpretation of the records.
